history.content:
Apparently, it's poorly graded and more survey oriented than rigorously oriented to getting a job, but that was just based on asking people who took it a few years ago.

That said it's pretty useless compared to literally every other course you could take. If you're done with the undergrad foundations in math and statistics, take a grad course, and always feel free to apply to an energy company or an energy-oriented lab and get better support in doing renewables work.

children.subject: Hands down ee137a and b. Then get an internship. Also do ee130 and grow to ee 140 and ee142 and work with Professor Arias, or take a ton of MatSci courses (where I can't advise you so well but thin film technology, conductivity, courses on electronic material, etc. are the way to go) coupled with physics 105 111ab and 141ab for device understanding then into grad ee courses in the 230 range like 232

Thanks for the answer! I am actually not an EECS major, just minoring. I come from another engineering discipline, so I haven´t taken any upper division EECS class.

What EECS upper division classes would you recommend I take instead of EE 134, if I am interested in renewable energy?

history.content:
I’m planning on taking EE 134 because I am interested in solar panels. However the class seems to focus very heavily on advanced physics. People who have taken it, how useful do you think it was?? Did you enjoy it and feel you learned about the technology?

Any opinions or tips are appreciated
history.subject: EE 134 opinions
